title.narrative: Emergency response to the internally displaced persons (IDPs) affected by violence in the metropolitan area of Port-au-Prince

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving Child Protection, WASH, Child/Maternal Health and Nutrition assistance to vulnerable communities affected by violence outbreaks. This UNICEF project provides child-friendly spaces in the existing IDPs temporary shelters, access to safe drinking water, sanitation and hygiene facilities, integrated health services for the IDPs, and referral and treatment for moderate and acute malnutrition for children aged 6 to 59 months. The project provides life-saving assistance to 14,000 people, including 4,182 women, 3,826 men, 5,992 children, and 770 persons with disabilities.

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

title.narrative: RESIDENT / HUMANITARIAN COORDINATOR REPORT ON THE USE OF CERF FUNDS HAITI RAPID RESPONSE VIOLENCE/CLASHES 2021

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: Child Protection - Girls and boys affected by the armed violence in the metropolitan area of Port-au-Prince are supported by multidisciplinary activities through a community-based approach, and receive psychosocial support to fight psychological distress, including those who have specific needs.
# of children (2,500 girls and 2,500 boys) who regularly participate in child friendly spaces, with a follow-up file.
# of children (300 girls and 300 boys) referred who have received a package of services following a case study by the social workers’ team
# of people (300 women and 200 men) who participated in the talking groups and who have been referred for ad-hoc assistance
Child/Maternal Health and Nutrition - IDPs in relocation sites of target neighborhoods, have an immediate access to integrated health services to satisfy their urgent needs
# of 6 – 59 months children referred for moderate and acute malnutrition through mobile PTA or mobile clinics (MAM: 103, SAM: 111)
# of on-site 20-49 years old women, 0-59 months boys and girls children, and 15-19 years old adolescents benefited by health services
N.4 Number of people screened for acute malnutrition (# of 6 – 59 months children screened for acute malnutrition and receiving supplement Vitamin A)
N.5 Number of people receiving vitamins and/or micronutrient supplements

N.6 Number of people benefitting training and/or community awareness sessions on infant and young child feeding in emergencies (mothers, caregivers and parents receiving preventive activities to promote breastfeeding, introduce complementary feeding, promote hygiene, and adequate/ appropriate feeding practice)

WASH - IDPs in temporary shelters and the most vulnerable households out of shelter, in vulnerable neighbourhoods of Port au Prince, have immediate access to WASH facilities, supplies and services to satisfy their urgent needs
Number of IDPs in the shelters benefiting from access to emergency WASH services
